title: Beijing Chosen to Host 2022 Winter Olympics
content:
BEIJING—The last time China ’ s capital bid to host the Olympics , people stayed up late waiting for the televised announcement and then spent a sleepless night celebrating Beijing ’ s win . This time , the celebration was brief .
The International Olympic Committee on Friday voted 44-40 to award the 2022 Winter Games to Beijing , in a joint bid with Zhangjiakou , a nearby city abutting mountains with ski resorts . Its sole rival was the remote Central Asian city of Almaty , Kazakhstan , and the decision makes Beijing the first city to host both the winter and summer competitions , following the 2008 Olympics .
People paused in the middle of the evening rush hour to watch the IOC announcement on television and mobile phones . A momentary cheer went up outside one office and shopping complex as people took cellphone videos of a large-screen monitor above the entrance . Then the crowd hurried off .
“ I don ’ t really care about it , ” said Zhang Shuo , a 30-year-old financial analyst with Huatai Insurance Group . “ Those winter sports activities aren ’ t my affair , and they ’ re very expensive . ”
By contrast , 14 years ago , the capital erupted in triumph . Cars honked their horns while people stood on top waving the red national flag . Strangers hugged . “ I was so excited that I opened the windows to my home and shouted ‘ We won ! ’ ” said Mr. Zhang . “ It was really an exciting and happy moment for all Beijing people and all Chinese I think . ”
Reasons for the low-key response range from winter sports being less popular in China to a more muted publicity campaign by Beijing in deference to the IOC ’ s new mandate to rein in the spiraling costs of the games . But chief among the mood-dampeners , according to officials , experts and locals , is that having already hosted an Olympics that to many Chinese marked the country ’ s triumphant return to the world stage , playing host a second time would be less freighted with significance .
The Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics at a Glance According to the Beijing 2022 Bid Book and state media : Beijing will become the first city in history to host both a Summer and Winter Games .
Total budget : $ 3.9 billion ( $ 1.98 billion for operations , $ 1.92 billion for infrastructure ) .
Not included in the budget : A new 108-mile high-speed train line linking Beijing with mountain venues .
Number of venues : 12 , half recycled from the 2008 Summer Games .
Average snow depth at alpine skiing venue in February : 5.3 inches .
“ Chinese are starting to enjoy the games more and are a little less nationalistic , ” said Xu Guoqi , a historian at Hong Kong University who has researched China ’ s involvement with the Olympics . “ They ’ ve been there , done that . ”
Government propaganda and school textbooks for decades depicted the Olympics as a proxy measure for national strength . Holding the 2008 Olympics—and winning the most gold medals—allowed China to end “ this long-term obsession , ” said Mr. Xu .
Those games brought China praise for iconic venues such as the National Stadium , known as the Bird ’ s Nest , and the clockwork proficiency of the operations . Chinese leaders were so unnerved by the prospect of unruly crowds of Chinese or protests by foreign activists that they smothered the games in security . Visas were hard to obtain . Beijing residents were told to stay home and watch TV . Foreign commentators referred to the “ no fun ” games .
Beijing ’ s message to the IOC , as Vice Premier Liu Yandong put it in a formal presentation in June , is that it is “ the safe and reliable choice . ”
To meet the IOC ’ s goal of a more affordable games , Beijing is reusing or converting six venues from 2008 and building six new ones , all but one of them in the far suburbs of Yanqing or at Zhangjiakou , where the skiing and sledding events will be held . The combined operating and capital budget for the games is a projected $ 3.9 billion , compared with $ 4.6 billion in 2008 .
As with the 2008 Olympics—for which the government and state companies spent an additional $ 36 billion in redeveloping Beijing , adding subway lines and building bedroom communities to house people relocated from the redesigned city—China is expected to spend far beyond the official event budget .
China ’ s state-run Xinhua News Agency reported in July that the games would bring 350 billion yuan ( $ 56.4 billion ) in investment , mostly for Zhangjiakou , a city of rust-belt industries , and the surrounding , largely poor rural areas . A high-speed rail line connecting Beijing to Zhangjiakou is already being laid with or without the Olympics , financed and built by state-run railway engineering companies .
In its final presentation to the IOC meeting in the Malaysian capital of Kuala Lumpur on Friday , China ’ s team touched upon the prospects of bringing the games to the large Chinese market .
“ We will create unparalleled development opportunities , not just in China but for the world , ” Vice Premier Liu said . “ It is about the future of winter sports . ”
If 2008 was about national ambitions , 2022 seems directed at addressing a more prosperous population eager for leisure activities . “ There ’ s an emerging middle class and they have the time and the money and need the space to enjoy themselves , ” said Zhang Chunsheng , a Zhangjiakou official and deputy director of the bid committee . “ We hope we can meet the needs of this emerging middle class . ”
The disposable income of greater Beijing ’ s 21 million residents has nearly doubled since 2008 , to 43,910 yuan per capita last year . The ski resorts outside Zhangjiakou once struggled to lure skiers to their cold , icy hills but are now packed on winter weekends with Beijingers who cram into their sport-utility vehicles for the three-hour drive .
Not everyone is a fan . Amid the thousands of performers the Beijing government organized to watch the IOC ceremony outside the Bird ’ s Nest stadium on Friday was 21-year-old subway worker Xiao Shuai . Beijing ’ s win is good , he said , because it likely means the construction of more subway lines , though he isn ’ t interested in winter sports .
“ I don ’ t ski myself , ” he said . “ It is hard to get to Zhangjiakou , and skiing is too expensive . ”
—Olivia Geng in Beijing and Will Davies in Hong Kong contributed to this article .
